unhu_ubuntu.title: Unhu/Ubuntu: The Foundation of Shona Culture
unhu_ubuntu.description: The principle of 'I am because we are' - emphasizing community, compassion, and mutual respect
unhu_ubuntu.importance: This philosophy guides all social interactions and language use in Shona culture
practicalApplication: Always greet people properly before any interaction
Use respectful language, especially with elders
Consider the community impact of your words and actions
Show genuine interest in others' wellbeing
unhu_ubuntu.languageConnection: This is why Shona has formal and informal pronouns - language itself embodies respect

greetings.title: The Sacred Art of Greetings
greetings.description: Greetings in Shona culture are not just pleasantries but sacred exchanges that acknowledge each person's humanity
greetings.culturalSignificance: A proper greeting establishes respect, shows cultural awareness, and opens the door to meaningful connection
guidelines: Always greet before beginning any conversation or request
Use 'mhoroi' (formal) with elders, strangers, or to show respect
The plural of respect: use plural forms when addressing elders or showing respect
Take time for greetings - rushing through them is considered rude
commonMistakes: Rushing through greetings to get to business
Forgetting to ask about someone's wellbeing

family_structure.title: The Extended Family System
family_structure.description: Shona families are extended networks where everyone has a role and responsibility
keyPrinciples: Extended family members are as important as immediate family
Children belong to the community, not just parents
Older siblings have authority and responsibility over younger ones
respectHierarchy: Mukoma (older brother) and Mainini (older sister) - sibling respect
Mwana (child) - to be guided and protected
family_structure.languageReflection: Family terms are used as respectful addresses even for non-family members

market_culture.title: Markets as Social Centers
market_culture.description: Traditional Shona markets are much more than commercial spaces - they're community gathering places
socialAspects: Markets are places to catch up on community news
Vendors and customers often develop long-term relationships
Bargaining is expected and shows engagement, not disrespect
Markets are places where different regions and cultures meet
etiquette: Always greet vendors before asking about prices
Show respect for the goods being sold
Be prepared to engage in friendly conversation
Bargaining should be done with humor and respect
culturalFoods: Sadza - the staple food, made from maize meal

language_as_music.title: Shona: A Musical Language
language_as_music.description: Shona is inherently musical, with tones, rhythm, and flow that reflect the culture's rich musical heritage
tonalNature: High and low tones change word meanings
Tone patterns create the 'melody' of speech
Different emotions are expressed through tonal variations
Regional dialects have different tonal patterns
musicalElements: Connection to traditional music and dance
Praise singing and praise names (mazita okupfumbira)
practicalTips: Listen to Shona music to internalize rhythm
Pay attention to the 'music' in conversations
Don't worry about perfect tones initially - focus on communication

traditional_values.title: Core Traditional Values
traditional_values.description: Values that guide behavior and are reflected in language use
modernApplication: These values are still very much alive in modern Zimbabwe
They influence business practices and social interactions
Understanding these values helps in building meaningful relationships
They provide a framework for ethical behavior

regional_variations.title: Regional Dialects and Variations
regional_variations.description: While Standard Shona is taught, regional variations add richness to the language
regional_variations.standardShona: Based primarily on Zezuru and Karanga dialects
regional_variations.respectForVariations: All dialects are valued and contribute to the rich tapestry of Shona culture
regional_variations.practicalAdvice: Learn Standard Shona first, then appreciate regional variations as you encounter them

ceremonial_language.title: Ceremonial and Formal Language
ceremonial_language.description: Special language forms used in traditional ceremonies and formal occasions
ceremonial_language.importance: Understanding formal language shows deep cultural respect and knowledge

modern_adaptations.title: Shona in the Modern World
modern_adaptations.description: How traditional Shona culture and language adapt to contemporary life
urbanVsRural: Urban Shona may incorporate more English words
Rural areas maintain more traditional forms
Both are valid and evolving forms of the language
technology: WhatsApp and social media use in Shona
Radio and TV programming in Shona
globalization: Shona speakers worldwide maintaining their culture
